In Table III, we present the MSE and running time of IDC estimators with $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{T}$ and $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P}$ as initial estimators, respectively, for two different numbers of iterations $S$. Comparing MSEs of three IDC estimators with different initial values: $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ (Table I) and $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{T}$ (Table III) or $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P}$ (Table III), we observe that the IDC estimator with the consistent initial estimator reduces the MSEs for the same number of iterations.

![table_3](table_3)

Table IV: MSE comparison of competing estimators. Number of iterations $S=20$.

Table IV presents MSEs of different estimators for three $(d, n)$ pairs each. We set the largest $d$ be 50 so that MLE can be computed in a reasonable time. $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P B}^{I}, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{T}^{I}$, and $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P}^{I}$ denote the IDC estimators with $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{T}$, and $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P}$ as the initial estimators respectively. Besides DGP-A, we consider two additional DGPs to study the performance of the IDC estimator under different data settings. In all DGPs, we let $p=5$.

DGP-B [Poisson]: The random variable $\boldsymbol{V}$ follows a standard normal distribution; $C_{i k}$ follows a Poisson distribution with mean $e^{n_{i k}^{n}}$; and $M$ is obtained by summing up realizations of the Poisson draws for different choices.

DGP-C [Mixture]: We let $\boldsymbol{V}$ follow a mixture of Gaussian distributions with means 0 and 4 with standard deviations 1 for both distributions. $M$ is also set to follow a mixture of Gaussian distributions with means 10 and 60 and rounded to the closest integer. The standard deviations are 1 and 5 respectively. We have made these modifications so that some choices are rarely selected and ensure the robustness of our estimator in those cases.

Based on the simulation result, our IDC algorithm is successfully executed for all DGPs and exhibits stability. In contrast, we encounter errors for DGP-C when computing the estimators in Böhning and Lindsay (1988), Böhning (1992), and Simon et al. (2013). We see from Table IV that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P B}^{I}$ performs close to $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ for all DGPs and $(d, n)$ pairs. In DGP-B, the initial estimator $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P}$ is the maximum likelihood estimator. As a result, $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P}^{I}$ starts with not only a consistent but asymptotically efficient initial estimator. Even in this case, $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P B}^{I}$ has comparable MSEs.

In summary, the IDC estimators with all three initial estimators have finite sample performance similar to the MLE for the DGPs studied in this section. They are much

faster to compute than the MLE for large $d$ and are feasible even when the MLE might be intractable. Moreover, if the IDC estimator starts with the consistent initial estimator $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$, its finite sample performance will be further improved and is almost the same as the MLE.

# 5.2 Inference 

In this section, we illustrate the bootstrap inference procedure introduced in Section 4.2. We investigate the finite sample performance of the procedure including the size and power. All the results are based on one thousand Monte Carlo repetitions, where the number of bootstrap repetitions is five hundred.

We consider the null hypothesis that some element of $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$ equals to a specific value. Data are generated from DGP-A introduced in the previous section. Let the null and the alternative hypotheses be that $H_{0}: \theta_{11}^{*}=0$ and $H_{1}: \theta_{11}^{*} \neq 0$. The test statistic is computed as $\left|\frac{\widehat{\theta}_{11}^{*}}{\widehat{s e}_{b}\left(\widehat{\theta}_{11}^{*}\right) / \sqrt{n}}\right|$, where $\widehat{s e}_{b}\left(\widehat{\theta}_{11}^{*}\right)$ is the bootstrap estimate of the standard error of $\widehat{\theta}_{11}^{*}$. The number of iterations is 10 when computing the IDC estimator. We set the nominal size as $5 \%$ and use the $97.5 \%$ quantile of the standard normal distribution as the critical value.

![table_4](table_4)

Table V: Finite sample rejection probabilities for different values of $\theta_{11}^{*}, n$, and $d$

In Table V, we report the finite sample rejection probabilities of our test for different values of $\theta_{11}^{*}$. Values in the first row of the table indicate the deviation of $\theta_{11}^{*}$ from the null hypothesis. When the deviation is zero, the null hypothesis is true. It can be seen from the table that the finite sample rejection rates get closer to the nominal size when the sample size increases. And when the true value $\theta_{11}^{*}$ deviates more from the null hypothesis, the rejection probabilities increase. The same pattern appears for both $d=20$ and $d=50$. The finite sample performance of the test when $d=50$ is not as good as that when $d=20$. This is predictable because there are many more unknown parameters in the model when $d=50$ than when $d=20$. We expect the results to improve as the sample size increases for any fixed $d$.

# 6 Conclusion 

In this paper, we propose an iterative distributed computing estimator for the multinomial logistic model that is fast to compute even when the number of choices is large. When the number of iterations goes to infinity, we show that our estimator is both consistent and asymptotically efficient. Based on the simulation study, the computational time of our estimator increases linearly with the number of choices. Moreover, our estimator has comparable finite sample performance to MLE when the latter is computationally feasible.

Extensions abound. First, our IDC estimator can be combined with several existing algorithms to accommodate more complex settings. For example, when minimizing $Q_{k n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}\right)\right)$ for $k=1, \ldots, d$, we can replace the gradient of the objective function with its stochastic approximation calculated from a randomly selected subset of the data. Such an algorithm is an online algorithm and might reduce the running time especially when $n$ is large. We can also employ a one-step Newton-Raphson to compute $\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} \in \Theta_{k}} Q_{k n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}\right)\right)$ in each iteration or even replace the Hessian matrix with its dominant. These modifications to the IDC estimator have the potential to further enhance computational efficiency, depending on the application. However, their theoretical properties require further investigation. Second, the asymptotic properties of the IDC estimator in this paper are established for a large but fixed number of choices. Asymptotic theory allowing for the number of choices to diverge with the sample size is yet to be established. Third, in cases where the number of covariates is also large, $\ell_{1}$ or $\ell_{2}$ regularization could be adopted. In a companion paper, we develop an asymptotic theory for a regularized iterative distributed computing estimator.

# Appendix A Notations and Equalities 

In this appendix, we list the mathematical expressions and equalities used in the paper.

1. $\operatorname{MNL}\left(\boldsymbol{C}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}, M_{i}\right) \equiv \frac{M_{i}!}{C_{i 1}!\cdots C_{i d}!}\left(\frac{e^{\eta_{i 1}}}{\Lambda_{i}}\right)^{C_{i 1}} \cdots\left(\frac{e^{\eta_{i d}}}{\Lambda_{i}}\right)^{C_{i d}}$
2. $l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[\boldsymbol{C}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}-M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right)\right]$
3. $L_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \equiv p \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$
4. $Q_{n}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \equiv-l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$
5. $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q_{n}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$
6. $l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu}) \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[\boldsymbol{C}_{i}^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}+\mu_{i} \mathbf{1}_{d}\right)-M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}+\mu_{i}}\right)\right]=l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$
7. $f(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu}) \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right)+M_{i} \mu_{i}-e^{\mu_{i}} \sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right]$
8. $q l_{C \mid V}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu}) \equiv l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})+f(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{d}\left(C_{i k}\left(\eta_{i k}+\mu_{i}\right)-e^{\left(\eta_{i k}+\mu_{i}\right)}\right)$
9. $Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu}) \equiv-q l_{C \mid V}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})$
10. $(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\mu}})=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta, \boldsymbol{\mu} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}} Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})$,
11. $Q_{k n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}, \boldsymbol{\mu}\right) \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(e^{\left(\boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}+\mu_{i}\right)}-C_{i k}\left(\boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}+\mu_{i}\right)\right)$
12. $\overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \equiv\left(\log \left(\frac{M_{1}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{1 k}}}\right), \ldots, \log \left(\frac{M_{n}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{n k}}}\right)\right)^{\prime}$
13. $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}=\left[\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1} \in \Theta_{1}} Q_{1 n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}\right)\right), \ldots, \arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{d} \in \Theta_{d}} Q_{d n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{d}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}\right)\right)\right]^{\prime}$
14. $l_{C_{k}, C_{d} \mid V, N_{k}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}\right) \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[C_{i k} \boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}-\left(C_{i k}+C_{i d}\right) \log \left(e^{\boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}+1\right)\right]$
15. $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k} \in \Theta_{k}}-l_{C_{k}, C_{d} \mid V, N_{k}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}\right)$
16. $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{T}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{T}\right)$ with $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{T}=\left(\log \left(M_{1}\right), \ldots, \log \left(M_{n}\right)\right)^{\prime}$
17. $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathbf{0})$
18. $Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \equiv Q_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{d}\left(\frac{M_{i} e^{\boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}}-C_{i k} \boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}-C_{i k} \log \left(\frac{M_{i}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}}\right)\right)$
19. $Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \equiv \sum_{k=1}^{d} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}}-C_{k} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}-C_{k} \log \left(\frac{M}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}}\right)\right)\right]$
20. $Q_{k}^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}\right) \equiv \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}}-C_{k} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}-C_{k} \log \left(\frac{M}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}}\right)\right]$
21. $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \equiv \arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$
22. $Q^{*}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right) \equiv p \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} Q_{n}^{*}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)$

23. $\mathcal{I}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right) \equiv \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \theta \partial \theta^{\prime}} Q^{*}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)$
24. $\frac{\partial^{2} Q^{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \theta \partial \theta^{\prime}} \equiv\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{j}}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}} \boldsymbol{V} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right] & \cdots & \mathbf{0} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \mathbf{0} & \cdots & \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{d}}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}} \boldsymbol{V} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right]\end{array}\right]$
25. $\frac{\partial^{2} Q^{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} \equiv\left[\begin{array}{ccc}\mathbb{E}\left[-\frac{M e^{2 \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}}}{\left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}\right)^{2}} \boldsymbol{V} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right] & \cdots & \mathbb{E}\left[-\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}+\boldsymbol{\theta}_{d}\right)}}{\left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}\right)^{2}} \boldsymbol{V} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right] \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ \mathbb{E}\left[-\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}+\boldsymbol{\theta}_{d}\right)}}{\left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}\right)^{2}} \boldsymbol{V} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right] & \cdots & \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{2 \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{d}}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}} \boldsymbol{V} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right]\end{array}\right]$
26. $\hat{\mathbf{1}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \boldsymbol{C}_{i}, \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right) \equiv \frac{d}{d \boldsymbol{\theta}} \log \operatorname{MNL}\left(\boldsymbol{C}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}, M_{i}\right)$
27. $\tilde{\mathbf{1}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \boldsymbol{C}_{i}, \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right) \equiv \mathcal{I}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \hat{\mathbf{1}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \boldsymbol{C}_{i}, \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right)$

# Appendix B Proofs 

Proof of Lemma 2.1: It holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu}) & =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[\boldsymbol{C}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}+\mu_{i} \boldsymbol{C}_{i}^{\prime} \mathbf{1}_{n}-M_{i} \log \left(e^{\mu_{i}} \sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right)\right] \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[\boldsymbol{C}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}+\mu_{i} \sum_{k=1}^{d} C_{i k}-M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right)-M_{i} \mu_{i}\right] \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[\boldsymbol{C}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\eta}_{i}-M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right)\right] \\
& =l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second to last equality holds because $\mu_{i} \sum_{k=1}^{d} C_{i k}=M_{i} \mu_{i}$. Therefore, adding $\mu_{i}$ does not change the likelihood.

Proof of Lemma 2.2: Notice that $Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})$ is differentiable w.r.t. $\boldsymbol{\mu}$ for any given $\boldsymbol{\theta}$. By letting $\frac{\partial Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\mu}}=\mathbf{0}$, we can obtain function $\overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ such that $\left.\frac{\partial Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\mu}}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\mu}=\overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}=$ $\mathbf{0}$ for every $\boldsymbol{\theta}$. By definition,

$$
Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})=-\left[l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})+f(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})\right]=-\left[l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})+f(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})\right]
$$

which implies that $\frac{\partial Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\mu}}=\frac{\partial f(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\mu}}$. Since $\frac{\partial f(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})}{\partial \mu_{i}}=M_{i}-e^{\mu_{i}} \sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}$, we obtain the expression of $\overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ as in (3.3). Plugging it into (2.5), we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right) \\
= & -\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right)+M_{i} \log \left(\frac{m_{i}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}}\right)-e^{\log \left(\frac{M_{i}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}}\right)} \sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right] \\
= & -\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right)+M_{i} \log M_{i}-M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right)-\left(\frac{M_{i}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}}\right) \sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right] \\
= & -\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[M_{i} \log M_{i}-M_{i}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

which does not depend on $\boldsymbol{\theta}$. As a result, it holds that

$$
\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right) \equiv \arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta}\left[Q_{n}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-f\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right)\right]=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q_{n}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

Because $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}))$, we have that

$$
\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q_{n}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}
$$

The claimed lemma then follows.

Proof of Lemma 3.1: By Equation (2.1), it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Pr}\left(C_{i k}, C_{i d} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right) \\
= & \frac{M_{i}!}{C_{i k}!C_{i d}!\left(M_{i}-C_{i k}-C_{i d}\right)!}\left(\frac{e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}}{\Lambda_{i}^{*}}\right)^{C_{i k}}\left(\frac{e^{\eta_{i d}^{*}}}{\Lambda_{i}^{*}}\right)^{C_{i d}}\left(\frac{\Lambda_{i}^{*}-e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}-e^{\eta_{i d}^{*}}}{\Lambda_{i}^{*}}\right)^{M_{i}-C_{i k}-C_{i d}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Because $N_{i k}=C_{i k}+C_{i d}$, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}\left(C_{i k}, C_{i d} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right) & =\operatorname{Pr}\left(C_{i k}, C_{i d}, N_{i k} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Pr}\left(C_{i k}, C_{i d} \mid N_{i k}, \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right) \operatorname{Pr}\left(N_{i k} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Compute $\operatorname{Pr}\left(N_{i k} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right)$ as

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left(N_{i k} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right)=\frac{M_{i}!}{N_{i k}!\left(M_{i}-N_{i k}\right)!}\left(\frac{e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}+e^{\eta_{i d}^{*}}}{\Lambda_{i}^{*}}\right)^{N_{i k}}\left(\frac{\Lambda_{i}^{*}-e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}-e^{\eta_{i d}^{*}}}{\Lambda_{i}^{*}}\right)^{M_{i}-N_{i k}}
$$

Together with Equations (B.2) and (B.3), we obtain that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}\left(C_{i k}, C_{i d} \mid N_{i k}, \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right) & =\frac{N_{i k}!}{C_{i k}!C_{i d}!}\left(\frac{e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}}{e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}+e^{\eta_{i d}^{*}}}\right)^{C_{i k}}\left(\frac{e^{\eta_{i d}^{*}}}{e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}+e^{\eta_{i d}^{*}}}\right)^{C_{i d}} \\
& =\operatorname{Pr}\left(C_{i k}, C_{i d} \mid N_{i k}, \boldsymbol{V}_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By replacing $e^{\eta_{i d}^{*}}$ with 1 because $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{d}^{*}=\mathbf{0}$, we obtain the claimed result.
Proof of Lemma 3.2: Under the assumption that $\operatorname{Pr}\left(M_{i} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}\right)=\operatorname{Po}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}\right)$, we can obtain that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}\left(\boldsymbol{C}_{i} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}\right) & =\operatorname{Pr}\left(\boldsymbol{C}_{i} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}, M_{i}\right) \operatorname{Po}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}\right) \\
& =\prod_{k=1}^{d} \operatorname{Po}\left(e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}\right)=\prod_{k=1}^{d} \frac{e^{\eta_{i k}^{*} C_{i k}} e^{-e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}}}{C_{i k}!}=\frac{\prod_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}^{*} C_{i k}}}{C_{i 1}!\cdots C_{i d}!} e^{-\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}^{*}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The log-likelihood function is written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log \left[\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\prod_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k} C_{i k}}}{C_{i 1}!\cdots C_{i d}!} e^{-\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}}\right] & \sim \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[\sum_{k=1}^{d} C_{i k} \eta_{i k}-\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right]=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{d}\left(C_{i k} \eta_{i k}-e^{\eta_{i k}}\right) \\
& =q l_{C \mid V}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathbf{0})
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{P}$ maximizes the true log-likelihood function based upon $\operatorname{Pr}\left(\boldsymbol{C}_{i} \mid \boldsymbol{V}_{i}\right)$. The lemma follows.

Lemma B.1. Under Assumption 4.2, $-L_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is convex in $\boldsymbol{\theta}$.

Proof of Lemma B.1: By the definitions of $l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $L_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and Assumption 4.2, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\frac{1}{n} l_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) & =-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[C_{i 1} \eta_{i 1}+\cdots+C_{i d} \eta_{i d}-M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\eta_{i k}}\right)\right] \\
& =-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left[C_{i 1} \boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}+\cdots+C_{i d} \boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{d}-M_{i} \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}_{i}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}\right)\right] \\
& \xrightarrow{p}-\left(\mathbb{E}\left[C_{1} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}\right]+\cdots+\mathbb{E}\left[C_{d} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{d}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[M \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}\right)\right]\right) \\
& \equiv-L_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \\
& =-\sum_{k=1}^{d} \mathbb{E}\left[C_{k} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[M \log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The first term is convex in $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ because it only involves linear functions. It has been shown in Section 3.1.5 in Boyd et al. (2004) that $\log \left(\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}}\right)$ is convex in $\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{d}$. Because $\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}$ is a linear function of $\theta_{k}$ and sums of convex functions are convex, the second term is convex in $\boldsymbol{\theta}$.

Lemma B.2. Under Assumption 4.2, $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$ is the unique fixed point of $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$.
Proof of Lemma B.2: By definition, $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \equiv \arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$. Thus, if we can show that $\left.\frac{\partial Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\mathbf{0}$ holds only at $\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$, then $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$ is the unique fixed point of $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\cdot)$. Taking the first order derivative of $-L_{C \mid V, M}(\cdot)$, we obtain that for any $\dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \in \Theta$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\left.\frac{d}{d \boldsymbol{\theta}} L_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}} & =\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}}}-C_{1} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right], \ldots, \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{d-1}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{k}}}-C_{d-1} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right]\right]^{\prime} \\
& =\left.\frac{\partial Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}\right|_{(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})=(\dot{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, \boldsymbol{\theta})}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, proving that $\left.\frac{\partial Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\mathbf{0}$ holds only at $\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$ is equivalent to showing that $\frac{d}{d \boldsymbol{\theta}} L_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathbf{0}$ only at $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$. By Lemma B.1, $-L_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is convex in $\boldsymbol{\theta}$. The set $\Theta$ is convex by Assumption 4.2. For a convex function over a convex set, any local minimum is also a global minimum. Along with the identification assumption in Section 2.1 that $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$ is the unique solution to $\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta}-L_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$, we obtain that $\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} L_{C \mid V, M}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathbf{0}$ holds only at $\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$.

Proof of Lemma 4.1: Part (i) follows by applying Theorem 2 in Jennrich (1969) on the uniform law of large numbers with conditions satisfied by Assumption 4.2.

Since $Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ is continuous in $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ and $\Theta$ is compact by Assumption 4.2 (i), $Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ achieves its minimum in $\Theta$ for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}$. Given any $0<\lambda<1$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{1} \neq \boldsymbol{\theta}^{2}$, if

$v_{j} \neq 0$ for $j=1, \ldots, p$, then we have

$$
e^{\boldsymbol{v}^{\prime}\left[\lambda \boldsymbol{\theta}^{1}+(1-\lambda) \boldsymbol{\theta}^{2}\right]}<\lambda e^{\boldsymbol{v}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{1}}+(1-\lambda) e^{\boldsymbol{v}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{2}}
$$

In consequence, $Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ is strictly convex in $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}$. Because $\Theta$ is a convex set, we have that $Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ have a unique minimizer for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}$. Part (ii) holds.

For part (iii), because $Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ is strictly convex in $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \Theta$ and $\Theta$ is convex, the (opposite) maximum theorem implies the continuity.

To prove part (iv), we take the first-order partial derivative of $Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ with respect to $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ and obtain that

$$
\frac{\partial Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}=\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}_{k}}}-C_{1} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right], \ldots, \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{d-1}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}_{k}}}-C_{d-1} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}\right]\right]^{\prime}
$$

Since $\mathbb{E}\left[C_{k} \mid \boldsymbol{V}, M\right]=\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}}$, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\frac{\partial Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}\right|_{(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, \boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)} \\
& =\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}}-C_{1} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \mid \boldsymbol{V}, M\right]\right], \ldots, \mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{d-1}^{*}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}}-C_{d} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \mid \boldsymbol{V}, M\right]\right]\right]^{\prime} \\
& =\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}}-\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}}\right], \ldots, \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{d-1}^{*}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}}-\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{d-1}^{*}} \boldsymbol{V}^{\prime}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}}\right]\right]^{\prime} \\
& =\mathbf{0} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Because $Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ is strictly convex in $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, Q^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)$ is certainly strictly convex in $\boldsymbol{\theta}$. Combining with (B.4), we obtain that $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \Theta} Q^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)$, which implies that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$.

Part (v) is proved by Lemma B.2.

Proof of Theorem 4.1: We show that if $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)} \xrightarrow{p} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$, then $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(1)} \xrightarrow{p} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$ as well. By (3.4), $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{(1)}$ satisfies that

$$
\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{(1)}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1} \in \Theta_{1}} Q_{1 n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}\right)\right)
$$

The first order condition provides that

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}} Q_{1 n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}\right)\right)\left.\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{(1)}}}=\mathbf{0}
$$

The mean value theorem implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{0} & =\left.\frac{1}{n} \frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}} Q_{1 n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}}+\left.\frac{1}{n} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}} Q_{1 n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{(1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}\right) \\
& \equiv A_{n}+B_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{(1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}$ lies between $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{(1)}$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}$. Since $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)} \xrightarrow{p} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$, we have that

$$
A_{n} \xrightarrow{p} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}} \boldsymbol{V}-C_{k} \boldsymbol{V}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{M e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}}}{\sum_{k=1}^{d} e^{\boldsymbol{V}^{\prime} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k}^{*}}} \boldsymbol{V}-C_{k} \boldsymbol{V} \mid \boldsymbol{V}, M\right]\right]=\mathbf{0}
$$

By a similar argument, it can be shown that $B_{n}$ converges in probability to a nonsingular matrix for any $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*} \in \Theta_{1}$. Therefore, it must hold that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{1}^{(1)} \xrightarrow{p} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{*}$. Hence, $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)} \xrightarrow{p} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ for any $S$.

Proof of Theorem 4.2: Based on Lemma 4.1, Assumptions 1, 2a, and 5 in Pastorello et al. (2003) are satisfied. Therefore, Proposition 1 in Pastorello et al. (2003) holds, which implies that as $n \rightarrow \infty$,

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \Theta}\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right\| \xrightarrow{p} 0
$$

where $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}(\cdot)$ is defined in (3.4).
Let $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)} \equiv p \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}$, where $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}$ is the initial value of our IDC estimator $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{I}$. Define $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(1)} \equiv \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right), \boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(2)} \equiv \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(1)}\right) \equiv \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{T}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right), \ldots, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)} \equiv \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s-1)}\right) \equiv \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right)$ for any $s \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$, where $\mathbb{Z}^{+}$denotes the set of positive integers. Next, we show that $\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)}\right)$ is a Cauchy sequence. By Assumption 4.3, we have that for any $s_{1}>s_{2} \geq 1$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\left(s_{1}\right)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\left(s_{2}\right)}\right\|= & \left\|\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{s_{1}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{s_{2}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right)\right\| \\
\leq & {\left[\left\|\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{s_{1}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{s_{1}-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right)\right\|+\left\|\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{s_{1}-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{s_{1}-2}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right)\right\| \right.} \\
& \left.+\cdots+\left\|\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{s_{2}+1}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{s_{2}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right)\right\|\right] \\
\leq & {\left[C^{s_{1}-1}+C^{s_{1}-2}+\cdots+C^{s_{2}}\right]\left\|\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(1)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right\| } \\
= & C^{s_{2}}\left[\sum_{i=0}^{s_{1}-s_{2}-1} C^{i}\right]\left\|\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(1)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right\| \\
\leq & C^{s_{2}}\left[\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} C^{i}\right]\left\|\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(1)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right\| \\
\leq & \frac{C^{s_{2}}}{1-C}\left\|\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(1)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies that $\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)}\right)$ is Cauchy because $C<1$. Since $\Theta \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{p d}$ is compact by Assumption 4.2 and $\mathbb{R}^{p d}$ is complete with respect to $\|\cdot\|, \Theta$ is also complete with

respect to $\|\cdot\|$. Therefore, $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)}$ converges to a limit $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\star}$ in $\Theta$ as $s \rightarrow \infty$. Because

$$
\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\star}\right)=\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)}\right)=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)}\right)=\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s+1)}=\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\star}
$$

it holds that $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\star}$ is a fixed point of the mapping $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}: \Theta \rightarrow \Theta$. By Lemma B.2, $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\star}$ is the unique fixed point of $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\cdot)$. Thus, $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\star}=\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\star}$ and $\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)}=\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\star}$.

We now show that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)}=o_{p}(1)$ for any $s \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$by induction. By the definition of $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(0)}=o_{p}(1)$. Assuming that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(t)}=o_{p}(1)$ for some $t$, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t+1)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(t+1)} & =\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(t)}\right) \\
& =\left[\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t)}\right)\right]+\left[\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(t)}\right)\right] \\
& =o_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last equality holds because $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t)}\right)=o_{p}(1)$ by (B.5), $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(t)}-$ $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(t)}=o_{p}(1)$ by assumption and $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\cdot)$ is continuous by Lemma 4.1 (iii). Therefore, $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)}=o_{p}(1)$ for any $s \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$.

Hence, we have that if $S \rightarrow \infty$ and $n \rightarrow \infty$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{I}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right\| & =\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(S)}\right\|+\left\|\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(S)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right\| \\
& \equiv A(n, S)+B(S) \xrightarrow{p} 0
\end{aligned}
$$

because $A(n, S) \xrightarrow{p} 0$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ for any given $S$ and $B(S) \rightarrow 0$ as $S \rightarrow \infty$ by $\lim _{s \rightarrow \infty} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{(s)}=\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{*}$. The theorem holds.

Lemma B.3. Under the conditions in Theorem 4.3, it holds that

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S+1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}\right) \xrightarrow{p} 0
$$

Proof of Lemma B.3: We first show that the result in the lemma holds if the conditions in part (i) of the theorem hold. By (3.4), for any $s \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}, \widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}$ satisfies that

$$
\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} Q_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}}=\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}}=\mathbf{0}
$$

Apply Taylor expansion to the left-hand-side of the equality at $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$. Because $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=$ $o_{p}(1)$ and $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=o_{p}(1)$, we obtain that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{*}}+\left.\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right) \\
& +\left.\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{*}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)=\mathbf{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

by ignoring higher-order terms. Since $\left.\frac{\partial^{2} Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}}$ is non-singular and both $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}$ and $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}$ are consistent estimators of $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$, we have that

$$
\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}}\right)^{-1}
$$

exists with a high probability when $n$ is large. Define

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A_{n} \equiv\left(\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}}\right)^{-1}\left(-\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}}\right) \\
& B_{n} \equiv\left(\left.\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}}\right)^{-1}\left(-\left.\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\prime}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By the law of large numbers and the consistency of $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}$ for any $s$, we have that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A_{n}=\left(\left.\frac{\partial^{2} Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}}\right)^{-1}\left(-\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} Q_{n}^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}}\right)+o_{p}(1) \equiv A+o_{p}(1) \\
& B_{n}=\left(\left.\frac{\partial^{2} Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}}\right)^{-1}\left(-\left.\frac{\partial^{2} Q^{\dagger}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\vartheta}^{\prime}}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}}\right)+o_{p}(1) \equiv B+o_{p}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

By ignoring the smaller order terms, we obtain from Equation (B.7) that

$$
\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=A+B\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s-1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)=\sum_{t=0}^{s-1} B^{t} A+B^{s}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)
$$

where the second equality follows from iterating the first equality. It then holds that

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S+1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}\right)=\sqrt{n} B^{S} A+\sqrt{n} B^{S}(B-I)\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)
$$

By Assumption 4.4, $\|B\|<1$, which implies that $\sqrt{n}\|B\|^{S} \rightarrow 0$ as $S \geq \log (n)$ and $n \rightarrow \infty$. Hence, $\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S+1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}\right)=o_{p}(1)$. The claimed lemma follows.

We now prove that under the conditions in part (ii) of the theorem, the result also holds. If we can show that for any $s \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$, with probability approaching one, there exists a constant $c<1$ such that

$$
\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right\| \leq c\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right\|
$$

then by the same derivation as (B.6), we would obtain that

$$
\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S+1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}\right\| \leq \frac{c^{S}}{1-c}\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}\right\|
$$

Because $c<1$ and $S>n^{\delta}$ for some $\delta>0$, it holds that

$$
\sqrt{n}\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S+1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}\right\| \leq \frac{n^{\frac{1}{\delta}} c^{S}}{1-c}\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(0)}\right\| \rightarrow 0
$$

Thus, it suffices to prove (B.8).
By the implicit function theorem, $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\cdot)$ is continuously differentiable in $\Theta$. Together with Assumption 4.3, we have that there exists $\epsilon>0$ such that for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \Theta$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}} \in \mathcal{B}^{\epsilon}(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})) \equiv\{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \Theta:\|\boldsymbol{\vartheta}-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})\| \leq \epsilon\}$, we have

$$
\|\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}})-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})\| \leq C_{\epsilon}\|\hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta}\|
$$

for some $C_{\epsilon} \leq \bar{C}<1$. By (B.5), $\operatorname{Pr}\left[\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right) \in \mathcal{B}^{\epsilon}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right)\right] \rightarrow 1$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ for any $s$ and $\epsilon$. Therefore, with probability approaching one, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right\| & =\left\|\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right\| \\
& \leq C_{\epsilon}\left\|\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right\|=C_{\epsilon}\left\|\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

For any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \Theta$, define $\Omega(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \equiv \frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\vartheta}} \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$, where $\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\vartheta}} \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ is the Jacobian matrix of dimension $d p \times d p$. By the implicit function theorem, we have

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\vartheta}} \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\left.\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} g(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\{\boldsymbol{\theta}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}), \boldsymbol{\vartheta}\}}\right]^{-1} \frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\vartheta}} g(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\{\boldsymbol{\theta}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}), \boldsymbol{\vartheta}\}}
$$

where $g(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \equiv \frac{\partial Q^{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}$ is the function that defines $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$. Similarly, we define $\Omega_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \equiv \frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\vartheta}} \overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ and $g_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \equiv \frac{\partial Q_{n}^{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}$. By Assumption 4.2 (ii) and (iii) and the uniform law of large numbers, we have

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \Theta}\left\|\Omega_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})-\Omega(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right\| \xrightarrow{p} 0
$$

By Assumption 4.2 (i), $\Theta$ is convex. Applying a multivariate Taylor expansion (Dieudonné (2011), p. 190), we can write $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}})-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\Lambda(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}})(\hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}} \in \Theta$, where

$$
\Lambda(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}}) \equiv \int_{0}^{1} \Omega(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}+\xi(\hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta})) d \xi
$$

Similarly, we have $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}})-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\Lambda_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}})(\hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}} \in \Theta$, where

$$
\Lambda_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}}) \equiv \int_{0}^{1} \Omega_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}+\xi(\hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}}-\boldsymbol{\vartheta})) d \xi
$$

It holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}\right)-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right\| \leq & \left\|\left[\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}\right)-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right]-\left[\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}\right)-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right]\right\| \\
& +\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}\right)-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right\| \\
\leq & \left\|\left[\Lambda_{n}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}})-\Lambda(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}})\right]\left[\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}\right)-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right)\right]\right\| \\
& +C_{\epsilon}\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first inequality follows from the triangular inequality and the second inequality holds by (B.9). Because the first term on the right-hand side has the order $o_{p}\left(\left\|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s+1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(s)}\right\|\right)$ because of (B.10), we have shown that (B.8) holds with $c=C_{\epsilon}<1$. The lemma follows.

Proof of Theorem 4.3: We aim to show that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}$ has the same influence function as $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$. By the definition of the IDC estimator in Section 3.2, we have that

$$
\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} Q_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}}=\mathbf{0}
$$

Applying the Taylor expansion to the function on the left-hand-side of the above equation round $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}$, we can obtain that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} Q_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}} \\
& +\left.\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} Q_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)=\mathbf{0}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}$ lies between $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}$ and $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}$. The definition of $Q_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})$ implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} Q_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}} \\
& =-\left.\frac{d}{d \boldsymbol{\theta}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)-\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} f\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Applying the expression of $f(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\mu})$, it can be shown that

$$
\left.\frac{\partial}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}} f\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}}=\mathbf{0}
$$

Therefore, (B.11) can be rewritten as

$$
-\left.\frac{d}{d \boldsymbol{\theta}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} Q_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \overline{\boldsymbol{\mu}}_{n}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)\right)\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right)=\mathbf{0}
$$

By Lemma B.3, we have $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S+1)}-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}=o_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$. This implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d}{d \boldsymbol{\theta}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}\right) & =o_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right) \\
& =\frac{d}{d \boldsymbol{\theta}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)+\frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\dagger}\right)\left(\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second equality follows from the Taylor expansion and $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\dagger}$ lies between $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$.

By Theorems 4.1 and 4.2, we have that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)} \xrightarrow{p} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ either for any fixed $S$ or as $S \rightarrow \infty$. Therefore, by Assumption 4.2 and Taylor's theorem, we can obtain that

$$
\frac{1}{n} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\dagger}\right)=\frac{1}{n} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)+o_{p}(1)
$$

Since matrix inversion is continuous (at non-singular matrices), it follows that the inverse of $\frac{1}{n} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)$ exists with high probability and

$$
\left[-\frac{1}{n} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta} \partial \boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)\right]^{-1} \xrightarrow{p} \mathcal{I}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)
$$

where $\mathcal{I}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)$ is the Fisher information matrix defined in Section 4.2. Using this result to (B.12), we obtain that

$$
\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=\mathcal{I}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right) \frac{1}{n} \frac{d}{d \boldsymbol{\theta}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)+o_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
$$

Since $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S-1)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}+o_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$ by Lemma B.3, it holds that

$$
\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=\mathcal{I}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right) \frac{1}{n} \frac{d}{d \boldsymbol{\theta}} l_{C \mid V, M}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)+o_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)
$$

It can be seen that $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}$ and the maximum likelihood estimator $\widetilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ have the same influence function. Hence, under the assumptions in either part (i) or (ii) of the theorem, we have $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(S)}-\widetilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=o_{p}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$.

Proof of Corollary 4.4: The result directly follows from Theorem 4.3 and the standard result on the asymptotic distribution of the maximum likelihood estimator.

Proof of Theorem 4.5: The proof of the theorem follows from the discussion in Section 4.2.

abstract:
This article introduces an iterative distributed computing estimator for the
multinomial logistic regression model with large choice sets. Compared to the
maximum likelihood estimator, the proposed iterative distributed estimator
achieves significantly faster computation and, when initialized with a
consistent estimator, attains asymptotic efficiency under a weak dominance
condition. Additionally, we propose a parametric bootstrap inference procedure
based on the iterative distributed estimator and establish its consistency.
Extensive simulation studies validate the effectiveness of the proposed methods
and highlight the computational efficiency of the iterative distributed
estimator.
